definition[0]: a large quantity of something that is carried by a vehicle, person etc
example[0]: The lorry had shed its load (=the load had fallen off).
example[1]: The plane was carrying a full load of fuel.
definition[1]: the amount of work that a person or machine has to do
example[3]: The computer couldn’t handle the load and crashed.
example[4]: My work load has doubled since Henry left.
example[5]: They hired more staff in order to spread the load.
example[6]: Hans has a heavy teaching load this semester.
definition[2]: a problem or worry that is difficult to deal with
example[7]: When someone is depressed, the extra load of having financial problems can make the situation worse.
example[8]: Knowing he was safe was a load off my mind (=I felt less worried).
example[9]: Coping with ill health was a heavy load to bear.
definition[3]: a quantity of clothes that are washed together in a washing machine
example[10]: I’ve already done three loads of laundry this morning.
definition[4]: the amount of weight that something is supporting
example[12]: It increased the load on the wheels.
definition[5]: an amount of electrical power that is being produced
definition[6]: to put a large quantity of something into a vehicle or container
example[14]: It took an hour to load the van.
example[15]: Will you help me load the dishwasher?
example[16]: Emma loaded all the groceries into the car.
example[17]: He loaded the cups onto a tray.
example[18]: She loaded up the car with camping gear.
definition[7]: to put a necessary part into something in order to make it work, for example bullets into a gun or film into a camera
example[19]: Did you load it with 200 or 400 film?
example[20]: Can you load the CD into the player, please?
definition[8]: to put a program into a computer
example[21]: The program takes a while to load.
example[22]: To load the file, press the ‘return’ key.
definition[9]: if a ship, aircraft etc loads, goods are put onto it
example[23]: The first ship to load at the new port was the ‘Secil Angola’.
example[24]: The boat called at Lerwick to load up with fresh vegetables.
definition[10]: an amount of goods or people transported on a road vehicle, train, or plane
example[25]: Rail cars are used to move the bigger loads.
example[26]: The lorry returned with a load of Spanish apricots.
example[27]: The plane was carrying a full load of passengers.
definition[11]: the amount of something that a person or organization has to do
example[29]: The firm’s computers are struggling to cope with the increased load.
example[30]: The network has to deal with a heavy load of telephone traffic.
definition[12]: an amount of money charged for managing an INVESTMENT FUND
example[31]: Because of the 5% load, only $950 of the $1,000 actually gets invested in your name.
example[32]: The new fund carries a front-end load (=an amount paid when the fund is first started) of 5.5%
definition[13]: to put goods into a road vehicle, train, boat, or plane to be transported
example[34]: The tankers set off as soon as they have been loaded.
definition[14]: to copy a computer program or file onto a computer
example[35]: The new software can be loaded easily onto most machines.
definition[15]: to include most or all of the charges at a particular period during the time that an insurance policy or INVESTMENT FUND is in use
example[36]: A lot of personal pension funds are front-end loaded (=make most of their charges when the fund is first started).
